Authors: Brian Brown V., Paul T. Smith
Title:
Combined molecular and morphological phylogeny of the
bee-killing flies, genus Melaloncha Brues (Diptera: Phoridae).
Keywords:
Combined molecular and morphological phylogeny of the
bee-killing flies, genus Melaloncha Brues (Diptera: Phoridae).
Systematic Entomology, in press.
Abstract:
The phylogeny of the bee-killing flies, genus Melaloncha
Brues (Diptera: Phoridae) is analyzed using six genes- cytochrome
oxidase I, 16S ribosomal DNA, 12S ribosomal DNA, NADH1 dehydrogenase,
28S ribosomal DNA, and CAD- plus 47 morphological characters. A total of
91 specimens, including eight outgroups and 83 Melaloncha (representing
70 species) were included in the analyses. Parsimony analysis of the
combined dataset produced a single most parsimonious tree with varied
Bremer and bootstrap support of interior nodes. Bayesian analysis of
molecules only and of morphology + molecules produced trees largely in
agreement with parsimony results, although with a few differences.
Supported groups included subfamily Metopininae, genus Melaloncha, and
subgenera Melaloncha s. s. and M. (Udamochiras) Enderlein. Within the
subgenera, the previously recognized M. furcata, M. cingulata, M.
ungulata, and M. stylata groups were recovered, as well as some new
groupings. The M. furcata group was placed as the sister-group of other
Melaloncha s. s., which is consistent with known host-attacking
behavior.
